dt: {bc}to deride or tease with taunting words

dt.t: boxers {wi}gibing{/wi} each other before a fight

pt: {sc}scoff{/sc} {sc}jeer{/sc} {sc}gibe{/sc} {sc}fleer{/sc} {sc}sneer{/sc} {sc}flout{/sc} mean to show one's contempt in derision or mockery. {sc}scoff{/sc} stresses insolence, disrespect, or incredulity as motivating the derision.
{sc}jeer{/sc} suggests a coarser more undiscriminating derision.
{sc}gibe{/sc} implies taunting either good-naturedly or in sarcastic derision.

pt.t: the saucy jackanapes {it}fleered{/it} at my credulity

pt: {sc}sneer{/sc} stresses insulting by contemptuous facial expression, phrasing, or tone of voice.
{sc}flout{/sc} stresses contempt shown by refusal to heed.

et: perhaps from Middle French {it}giber{/it} to shake, handle roughly
shortdef: to deride or tease with taunting words

dt.t: a story that doesn't {wi}jibe{/wi} with the facts

shortdef: to be in accord : agree —usually used with with

dt: {bc}to shift suddenly and forcibly from one side to the other
used of a fore-and-aft sail or its boom

dt.t: was the most amazed when he saw me work the boat to and again in the sea by the rudder, and how the sail {it}jibed{/it}, and filled this way or that way as the course we sailed changed
the cutter had lost all four foremost men by the violent {it}jibing{/it} of a boom

dt: {bc}to change a vessel's course when sailing with the wind so that as the stern passes through the eye of the wind the boom swings to the opposite side
{bc}to cause (a sail or vessel) to jibe

dt.t: this maneuver was bound to force her to {wi}jibe{/wi} her mainsail from one side to the other

shortdef: to shift suddenly and forcibly from one side to the other —used of a fore-and-aft sail or its boom
to change a vessel's course when sailing with the wind so that as the stern passes through the eye of the wind the boom swings to the opposite side
to cause (a sail or vessel) to jibe
